item.title: Convert ISO-8859-1 to UTF-8
item.description:
As far as I can tell, there is no native way of converting stupid ISO-8859-1 characters that can't be transposed to UTF-8. This would usually be caused by copy + paste from Word.

function iso8859_to_utf($in) {
	// double dash
	$out = str_replace(chr(150),chr(45),$in);
	// lsquo
	$out = str_replace(chr(145),chr(39),$out);
	// rsquo
	$out = str_replace(chr(146),chr(39),$out);
	// ldquo
	$out = str_replace(chr(147),chr(34),$out);
	// rdquo
	$out = str_replace(chr(148),chr(34),$out);

	return $out;
}

These are the most common, I suppose there's a more elegant solution using regular expressions.

I'm not sure why ASCII #150 can't be replaced with U+2014 (—). Common chars are probably safer though.

item.title: JQuery vs. plain
item.description:
JQuery and standard Javascript can interact (JQuery is a higher level abstraction of standard Javascript anyway), but it's best to stick to one method of DOM access.

if ($(this).val() == '') this.style.color='#999';

will work, as will

if (this.value == '') $(this).css('color', '#999');

But it should be

if ($(this).val() == '') $(this).css('color', '#999');

I do this all the time, and then wonder why $(this).style has no properties..

item.title: Empty controls (WCAG1 10.4)
item.description:
To meet requirement 10.4, you could use unobtrusive JQuery:

function defaultText(field) {
	if ($('#'+field).val() == 'Enter your '+field) {
		$('#'+field).css('color', '#aaa');
	}

	$('#'+field).focus(function() {
		$(this).css('background-color','#ff9');
		if ($(this).val() == 'Enter your '+field) {
			$(this).val('');
			$(this).css('color', '#000');
		}
	});

	$('#'+field).blur(function() {
		$(this).css('background-color','#fff');
		if ($(this).val() =='') {
			$(this).val('Enter your '+field);
			$(this).css('color', '#aaa');
		}
	});
}

var fields = Array('name', 'email', 'phone', 'message');
for (var i=0; i<fields.length; i++)
	defaultText(fields[i]);

Something like that? Then set the ID on the controls to 'xxxx', default value 'Enter your xxxx', and css color #000 (so users without Javascript won't need to squint at the form).

Update: I already did this turkey a while ago, but the above is slightly better for functioning it and less obtrusive. And the AJAX-style yellow background: swish.

item.title: See if a known machine is up
item.description:
Here's a neat trick, using backticks and laziness:

<?php


function down($ip) {
  $p = `ping -c1 -t1 $ip`;
  return rtrim(str_replace('%', '',
    substr($p, strpos($p, 'eived')+7, 3)));
}

if (down('10.1.1.6')) echo "uh oh\n";

?>

ie. send one ping to the IP, timeout after 1 second. The resulting string is manipulated to show the number in "100% packet loss" or "0% packet loss" (it will only be 100 or 0 for a single ping, obviously - 100 means it's down, 0 is up).

item.title: Googlemaps integration
item.description:
Simple integration for Googlemaps (the first script tag contains a URL string, broken here to fit on screen):

<script src="http://maps.google.com/maps?file=api&v=2&
  key=ABQIAAAAz2glLiCZA9cwx_W7F15_dxRw7z9gIfJXBTlxiGNDDGfPz8RNfRQLqNo
  3TCLFxRbVAeQCAfOmMffm1w" type="text/javascript"></script>

<script type="text/javascript">
//<![CDATA[

if (GBrowserIsCompatible()) {
  var mapAddress = new GMap2(document.getElementById("mapAddress"));
  mapAddress.setCenter(new GLatLng(geocode ref, zoom factor);
  mapAddress.addControl(new GSmallMapControl());
  var labelAddress = "<strong>Label</strong><br />Can use HTML";
  var markerAddress = new GMarker(mapAddress.getCenter());
  GEvent.addListener(markerAddress, "click", function() {
    markerAddress.openInfoWindowHtml(labelAddress);
  });
  mapAddress.addOverlay(markerAddress);
}

//]]>
</script>
  1. Place the empty mapAddress div referred to above where you want it on the page (I've cleverly/confusingly used the same name for the div and var..)
  2. The script call can go anywhere, make sure the API key is correct for the target site
  3. Apply CSS to the div for sizing, if it's smaller than 400 or so pixels wide, you'll probably want to add
div#mapAddress span {
  overflow: hidden;
}

Other notes:

Geocode coordinates look something like -37.831924,144.952658 (latitude, longitude). 13 is a fairly good zoom factor for Australian metro maps.

Each different URL (& subdomain) needs a new API key.

  • API key signup

item.title: SELECT .. WHERE .. LIKE
item.description:
Today's lesson in forgotten SQL lore: SELECT .. WHERE .. LIKE.

SELECT some_field
FROM a_table
WHERE lower(selector_field) LIKE lower('%keyword%')

This will work on pretty much any SQL.

% indicates 0 or more unspecified chars, or you could use _ for exactly one char. Enclose the whole string (with wildcards) in 's. Use lower to check apples with apples.

PSQL also has:

this is the same as
ILIKE Case insensitive LIKE (same as lowering both operands)
~~ LIKE
~~* ILIKE
!~~ NOT LIKE
!~~* NOT ILIKE
  • "This is what happens when you put SQL source code in the hands of a bunch of Unix hacks"
  • http://www.postgresql.org/docs/7.4/static/functions-matching.html

item.title: PNG transparency for IE6 revisited
item.description:
When using the AlphaImageLoader filter, the src can use either relative or absolute path, and despite most scripts using sizingMethod, the default value (image) is probably what you want to use anyway. Other values are crop and scale (for repeating backgrounds).

There is a boolean attribute enabled, but it defaults to true anyway.

.png {
  background:none;
  filter:progid:DXImageTransform.Microsoft.AlphaImageLoader(
    src='/absolute/path/to/image.png');
  cursor:pointer; /* if it's a link */
}

item.title: Open external links with jQuery
item.description:
To replace those nasty target="_blank"s, use some simple jQuery to intercept and window.open the link.

$(function() {
  $('a.target_blank').each(function() {
    $(this).click(function(){window.open(this.href);return false;});
  });
});

You could use a better selector than .target_blank, but that one is a pretty clear signal to other developers.

Also

$('a[@href^=http]').each(function() { ... });

could be useful to open new windows only for external URLs (ie. those starting with http).

And finally

$('a[@href^$=pdf]').each(function() { ... });

for PDFs.

traceroute to 203.21.79.47 (203.21.79.47), 30 hops max, 40 byte packets

 2  203.24.101.23 (203.24.101.23)  21.850 ms  9.978 ms  10.098 ms
 3  vic-gw.aanet.com.au (203.123.72.65)  10.555 ms  10.255 ms  11.236 ms
 4  AS9837.melbourne.pipenetworks.com (218.100.13.25)  10.119 ms  11.445 ms
  12.559 ms
 5  vmelbcust01-ge01.powertel.net.au (202.92.64.169)  11.718 ms  11.209 ms
  11.775 ms
 6  vMELBcore04-ge0119.powertel.net.au (202.138.192.24)  21.423 ms  11.326 ms
  11.755 ms
 7  serial4-cbw-gw.join.net.au (202.138.207.130)  14.244 ms  15.941 ms 
  14.652 ms
 8  serial2-cbw-gw.join.net.au (61.95.1.170)  14.507 ms  17.720 ms  14.694 ms
 9  mel (203.21.79.47)  17.727 ms !C  14.394 ms !C  15.320 ms !C

First of all, Ubuntu (Dapper) didn't come with traceroute in the core installation. Huh? It has traceroute6, but not the more useful IPv4 sibling. Future proofing gone mad.

A handy translation of the above would be:

[hop #] [FQDN] ([IP]) [packet 1] [packet 2] [packet 3]

Each line lists the details of the node and then the round trip time in milliseconds for each of three packets to reach that node and return. Other results following the time might include:

FlagWhat?
!H, !N, or !Phost, network or protocol unreachable
!Aaccess to the network is prohibited
!Caccess to the host is prohibited
!Ssource route failed
!F-<pmtu>fragmentation needed, the RFC1191 Path MTU Discovery value is displayed
!Xcommunication administratively prohibited
!Vhost precedence violation
!Cprecedence cutoff in effect
!<num>ICMP unreachable code <num>

item.title: Case insensitive attribute selector
item.description:
It appears that all versions of Safari are case insensitive when accessing CSS attribute selectors. An example, CSS first:

<p title="captioN">This caption will be gray in Safari only!</p>

In all other CSS-compatible modern browsers, this would not match since the case is different between CSS and HTML, but Safari will match it regardless.

This could be useful for separating out Safari-specific styles, as with * html.

item.title: Inner or outer join
item.description:
In MySQL there are three main joins: inner, natural (or left) and right.

  1. inner join 
    select s.id, t.id as othertable_id, t.title
from sometable s
inner join othertable t on s.id=t.sometable_id

    Returns all results joined only at the given key (dropping the on clause would give a cartesian prodct).

  2. natural/outer left join 
    select s.some_id, t.other_id, t.title
from sometable s
natural join othertable t using (some_id)

    Returns all results joined on the given key but will display unmatched counterparts in the second table.

  3. right join - counterpart to a natural/left join, but displaying unmatched rows from the first table. Kind of obscure, may not be implemented - avoid using.

  • http://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/5.1/en/join.html

item.description:

MySQL versions prior to 4.1 use a 16-byte hash to store PASSWORD() encrypted fields, whereas the newer versions use a 41-byte hash. This might be why you can't log in any more...

Export the passwords separately and re-encrypt at the other end.

item.title: Send XML to a HTTPS
item.description:
Essential for payment gateways:

#!/usr/bin/perl
use IPC:Open2;

my $post_url='https://www.payments.biz/gateway/reciever.script';
open2(*README, *WRITEME,
 "/usr/bin/curl -H 'Content-Type: text/xml' -d \@- $post_url");

my $xml_out=<<EOX;
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<root>
  <childElement>
  ...
  </childElement>
</root>
EOX

print WRITEME $xml_out;
close WRITEME;

my @response=<README>;
close README;

my $out=join('',@response);
print $out;
exit 0;

curl is the key here - there are a few packages for Perl, but it might just be easier to execute with Open2 if the response is small and easy to interpret.

  • http://www.dagblastit.com/https_post/perl_curl_https_post.html

item.title: Bash scripting
item.description:
This is definitely something worth looking into. For now, here's a Mac example to set a different /etc/hosts depending on your IP (good for local network/adsl workarounds).

#!/bin/bash

EN1IP=`ifconfig en1 | grep 'inet ' | cut -d' ' -f 2`
H_EN1IP=10.1.1.
W_EN1IP=192.168.0.

if echo "$EN1IP" | grep -q "$H_EN1IP"
then
    cp /etc/hosts.home /etc/hosts
    echo `date` "Location: home - $EN1IP" >> /var/log/hosts.log
else
    cp /etc/hosts.work /etc/hosts
    echo `date` "Location: work - $EN1IP" >> /var/log/hosts.log
fi

exit 0

Then you could set up a LaunchAgent in /Library/LaunchAgents

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<!DOCTYPE plist PUBLIC "-//Apple Computer//DTD PLIST 1.0//EN"
        "http://www.apple.com/DTDs/PropertyList-1.0.dtd">
<plist version="1.0">
<dict>
        <key>Label</key>
        <string>net.hostswapper</string>
        <key>ProgramArguments</key>
        <array>
                <string>/opt/loc</string>
        </array>
	<key>RunAtLoad</key>
	<true/>
</dict>
</plist>

Automatic host swapping!

Update: actually, this wouldn't work since the LaunchDaemon is called before a wireless IP is acquired. Back to the drawing board. Pinging a known IP (ie. the router) with a set interval might work better.

  • http://tldp.org/LDP/abs/html/

item.title: undef
item.description:
All scalars that have not been explicitly defined have the value of undef. You can also assign this value to a scalar. In this way, undef is pretty much like NULL...

my $a;
my $b=undef;

The thing is, you can't explicitly check for undef, so no

if ($b==undef) {...} # no

So, instead you need to

if (defined($b)) {...} # yes

I suppose that would be is_not_null or whatever. This is handy for setting and checking parameters to a function that aren't always needed.

  • More on Perl variables

item.title: Set up Email on Ubuntu (Dapper)
item.description:
This is a little complicated. I wanted a single, central IMAP server to check email on, kind of like GMail, only accessible through any standard email app (Mail.app in my case). I seem to be switching email servers and rebuilding machines on a regular basis, so I wanted this setup to provide a safe store for all my email. GMail was a good solution, but doesn't provide the full swag that an email app has. Also, I don't trust the big G as much as I once did.

  • First things first, postfix:

    1. apt-get install postfix libsasl2 sasl2-bin libsasl2-modules

      Select Internet site, then enter the correct FQDN.

    2. Add some config

      sudo postconf -e "home_mailbox = Maildir/"
sudo postconf -e "mailbox_command = "

    3. Then SASL config

      postconf -e 'smtpd_sasl_local_domain ='
postconf -e 'smtpd_sasl_auth_enable = yes'
postconf -e 'smtpd_sasl_security_options = noanonymous'
postconf -e 'broken_sasl_auth_clients = yes'
postconf -e 'smtpd_recipient_restrictions = permit_sasl_authenticated,
 permit_mynetworks,reject_unauth_destination'
postconf -e 'inet_interfaces = all'
echo 'pwcheck_method: saslauthd' >> /etc/postfix/sasl/smtpd.conf
echo 'mech_list: plain login' >> /etc/postfix/sasl/smtpd.conf

    4. Set up the certificate

      mkdir /etc/postfix/ssl
cd /etc/postfix/ssl/
openssl genrsa -des3 -rand /etc/hosts -out smtpd.key 1024
chmod 600 smtpd.key
openssl req -new -key smtpd.key -out smtpd.csr
openssl x509 -req -days 3650 -in smtpd.csr -signkey smtpd.key
 -out smtpd.crt
openssl rsa -in smtpd.key -out smtpd.key.unencrypted
mv -f smtpd.key.unencrypted smtpd.key
openssl req -new -x509 -extensions v3_ca -keyout cakey.pem
 -out cacert.pem -days 3650

    5. Then back to postfix

      postconf -e 'smtpd_tls_auth_only = no'
postconf -e 'smtp_use_tls = yes'
postconf -e 'smtpd_use_tls = yes'
postconf -e 'smtp_tls_note_starttls_offer = yes'
postconf -e 'smtpd_tls_key_file = /etc/postfix/ssl/smtpd.key'
postconf -e 'smtpd_tls_cert_file = /etc/postfix/ssl/smtpd.crt'
postconf -e 'smtpd_tls_CAfile = /etc/postfix/ssl/cacert.pem'
postconf -e 'smtpd_tls_loglevel = 1'
postconf -e 'smtpd_tls_received_header = yes'
postconf -e 'smtpd_tls_session_cache_timeout = 3600s'
postconf -e 'tls_random_source = dev:/dev/urandom'
postconf -e 'myhostname = server1.example.com'
/etc/init.d/postfix restart

    6. Start the SASL runtime config

      mkdir -p /var/spool/postfix/var/run/saslauthd

      Edit /etc/default/saslauthd, uncomment START and add

      START=yes
PARAMS="-m /var/spool/postfix/var/run/saslauthd -r"

      Change the PIDFILE value for 

      PIDFILE="/var/spool/postfix/var/run/${NAME}/saslauthd.pid"

      Fire it up

      /etc/init.d/saslauthd start

      telnet localhost 25 then ehlo localhost to see if it works. Look out for 250-STARTTLS and 250-AUTH.

  • Courier IMAP (forget SSL for now.. but it's a good idea, so definitely come back to it)

    apt-get install courier-imap

    Say no to web admin. Add some postfix config

    postconf -e 'home_mailbox = Maildir/'
postconf -e 'mailbox_command ='

    And

    /etc/init.d/postfix restart

  • Install Mutt for shell email viewing

    apt-get install mutt

    Set up the Maildir structure under the user home directory

    mkdir ~/Maildir ~/Maildir/cur ~/Maildir/new ~/Maildir/tmp
    • Config Mutt to read from IMAP
    • IMAP folders on Mutt

  • Finally, fetchmail

    apt-get install fetchmail

    Edit/add some settings in /etc/fetchmailrc

    set daemon 300        # Poll every 5 minutes
set syslog            # log through syslog facility
set postmaster root
set no bouncemail

defaults:
timeout 300
antispam -1
batchlimit 100

poll pop.mailserver.net protocol POP3 user "username" there with
 password "password" is localuser here

    Those poll directives are pretty straight forward. Edit /etc/default/fetchmail to get set up

    START_DAEMON=yes

    Then /etc/init.d/fetchmail start. You can /etc/init.d/fetchmail awaken for a manual fetch if the daemon isn't polling fast enough.

    The last step is getting fetchmail to access GMail (SSL certs required).

    openssl s_client -connect smtp.gmail.com:995 -showcerts

    Copy everything from -----BEGIN CERTIFICATE----- to -----END CERTIFICATE----- (including those labels) and save as /etc/ssl/certs/gmail.pem. You'll also need a cert from the issuer, Equifax Secure Certificate Authority, but Ubuntu already has one of those. Next, some ssl black magic:

    cd /etc/ssl/certs
c_rehash .

    See if it works (look out for an +OK Gpop ... ready code)

    openssl s_client -connect pop.gmail.com:995

    If all is OK, add your GMail user to /etc/fetchmailrc

    poll pop.gmail.com with proto POP3 and options no dns user
 "user@gmail.com" with password "password" is localuser here
 options ssl sslcertck sslcertpath "/etc/ssl/certs" keep

    Fetchmail is run as root, so you can lock /etc/fetchmailrc down to 0600. It's Reasonably Secure, but take all due precautions.

    • The basics, from Ubuntu
    • http://www.howtoforge.com/perfect_setup_ubuntu_6.06_p5
    • http://axljab.homelinux.org/Gmail_POP3_with_Fetchmail

item.title: Set up Apache2 (Dapper)
item.description:
From a clean install

  1. apt-get install apache2
  2. Enable PHP5 and Python support 
    apt-get install php5 php5-gd libapache2-mod-python php5-mysql

Apache configuration is now split accross a few locations, rather than a central file. I would copy the default site .conf in /etc/apache2/sites-available to the FQDN of the site (as a filename), then change config and delete the original default. Before you do that, enable the new one with a2ensite site and disable default with a2dissite default.

Similarly, enable and disable modules with a2enmod/a2dismod.

More details on apache .conf files later. That'll be a big one.

item.title: Set up Perl for Apache2 (Dapper)
item.description:
ImageMagick is a universe package in Dapper, so from a fresh install enable the extra repositories in /etc/apt/sources.list. Next, install:

apt-get install libhtml-template-perl libgd-gd2-perl
 libmail-sendmail-perl libdate-manip-perl libmagick9
 imagemagick perlmagick libxml-csv-perl

That should be a pretty good coverage for now. You can always apt-cache search perl package keywords for other packages and install as necessary.

Next, edit /etc/apache2/apache.conf or a site .conf and add in

AddHandler cgi-script .cgi .pl

<Files ~ "\.pl$">
Options +ExecCGI
</Files>

Works for me.

item.title: Set up MySQL on Ubuntu (Dapper)
item.description:
1. apt-get install mysql-server
  2. Change the root password: 
    mysqladmin -uroot password new-password
  3. Enable logging by uncommenting log in /etc/mysql/my.cnf. Then /etc/init.d/mysql restart the server to prime it up.

  4. If importing databases from an old system (even the same version), you'll get this error:

    error: 'Access denied for user 'debian-sys-maint'@'localhost'

    For a quick n' dirty fix, take out the two password attributes in /etc/msql/debian.cnf and then

    GRANT RELOAD, SHUTDOWN, PROCESS, SHOW DATABASES, SUPER,
 LOCK TABLES ON *.* TO 'debian-sys-maint'@'localhost'
 IDENTIFIED BY PASSWORD '';
flush privileges;

item.title: Shorthand if
item.description:
Should work on any C-style language (Perl below):

my $referred = ($referral eq 'something') ? 1: 0;

That would be:

my $referred = {};
if ($referral eq 'something') {
  $referred = 1;
} else {
  $referred = 0;
}

Or how about

($referred) ?
  # do something here
:
  # do something else
;

But that's kind of lazy.

item.title: sprintf
item.description:
sprintf, the C-style string formatting function can be used in stacks of different ways for Perl and PHP. The two that I want to remember today both use %f, but for different reasons:

  1. Format a 16-digit number from a scalar (this one needs to be a float since integers are too small to contain 16 digits)

    sprintf("%16.0f", $credit_card);

    So that would make something like 1234567812345678 from a scalar - by default, Perl seems to want to use scientific notation for such a big number.

  2. Format a currency (this one needs float to show the mantissa)

    sprintf("\$%.2f", $amt); # escape out the $

    ie. $320.87

% indicates a variable to substitute from the 2nd parameter, and in the above examples <integral digits>.<mantissa digits>, followed by f for floating-point.

  • More sprintf goodness

Apple, I understand that ENTER and RETURN are different, but it seems a little extravagant to give priority to ENTER over, say, FORWARD DELETE (or just DELETE for the 101 enhanced keyboard crowd). -o username=smbusername, password=smbpassword, iocharset=utf8,
 file_mode=0777, dir_mode=0777

If you want it automatic, add a line to /etc/fstab:

//netbiosname/share /mountpoint cifs
 username=smbusername,password=smbpassword,
 iocharset=utf8,file_mode=0777,dir_mode=0777 0 0

(you could store the user/pass in a file and point credentials at it for better security)

Now try it out with sudo mount -a.

  • http://ubuntuforums.org/showthread.php?t=288534

item.title: Pageinate a query
item.description:
The SQL part of pageination is easy with MySQL:

select * from sometable where clause=expr
 order by index_field limit 20, 10

ie. display 10 records, beginning at index 20 of the resultset. Now just feed the starting point with a paging script, and you're done.

item.title: Function arguments in Perl
item.description:
a.k.a. URGHHH...

The three ways you want to remember are:

  1. If you don't know exactly what's coming, roll it all in a hash:

    sub perlFunc {
  my %args = @_;
  print $args{what_was_that_again};

  return(%args);
}

  2. Or, if you do know what's coming:

    sub otherPerlFunc {
  my ($what_was_that_again, $oh_yeah, $never_mind) = @_;
}

  3. And finally, if it's a single parameter you might as well just:

    sub oneMorePerlFunc {
  my $singleValue = shift;
}

item.title: Hashes in Perl (part 1)
item.description:
Define a hash (associative array):

my %hash = ("key" => "value", currentlyPlaying => "Trans Am",
  "is_$someScalar" => 1);

Determine the number of elements in a hash (works on arrays too), similar to a .length() or UBound - use the scalar function:

my $hashLength = scalar %hash;
my $arrLength = scalar(@array); # this would work too

To quickly print out the contents of a hash, use keys:

print "Content-type:text/html\n\n";
foreach $k (keys %vars) { print "$k => ".$vars{$k}; }

That's it for now.

item.title: Here document
item.description:
PHP and Perl can both use here document for multi-line text, but the call and terminator are slightly different for each:

  1. PHP 
    print<<<ENDLABEL
  This is a PHP print here, complete with $variable
  interpolation. The terminator label must be on a line
  by itself at column 1.
ENDLABEL;
  2. Perl 
    my $text = <<END;
  This is how Perl does it. "Quotes" are fine.
END

(the terminator labels don't make a difference.. call it whatever you like)

item.title: Light weight Redirect
item.description:

<!DOCTYPE html PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD XHTML 1.0 Strict//EN"
  "http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-strict.dtd">
<html xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml">
<head>
  <title>Redirect..</title>
  <meta http-equiv="refresh"
    content="0;url=http://www.waitingallday.com">
</head>
<body>

</body>
</html>

(the first parameter of the refresh call is a delay in seconds before execution - set it to 0 for instant redirect)

item.title: Set up synergy using launchd
item.description:
Okay, this is a long one.

Synergy, if you've not heard of it, is a software KM switch (you know, like KVM.. only without the V) ie. you share a keyboard and mouse accross multiple machines that each have a dedicated monitor. It's kind of specialist and fancy, but it's more responsive than VNC and way more nerdy than just two keyboards.

  • http://synergy2.sourceforge.net

If, like me, you run a mac as your main machine and a PC for testing/fileserver/etc then you'll want the synergy server on the mac. No sweat. Only (at the moment anyway), the software is built for windows (service) or linux (daemon) environments. OS X is kind of like linux, right?

If you're familiar with linux-based systems then you'll have done a few /etc/init.d/apache2 restart (or fetchmail or whatever) 's in your time. You can't do this with Mac OS X, but Apple have provided something even better: lanuchd.

You probably want to look this up with Apple or read the man pages on this one, as it does a lot more than just restart daemons, but anyway it's good for our purposes.

  1. Set up the synergy config file somewhere. It has a pretty simple set of instructions:

    section: screens
  beng:
  beta9:
    alt = super
    super = alt
end

section: links
  beta9:
    right = beng9
  beng:
    left = beta9
end

section: aliases
  beng:
    beng.local
end

    So the mac, beng, is on the right and the PC, beta9 is on the left of beng. You'll see straight away if you've screwed this up. I don't remember where I got the alt/super mapping from, but it maps the Apple key to the Windows key and mac-alt to PC-alt.

  2. Next, you'll need to set up a LaunchDaemon plist under /Library/LaunchDaemons like this (my synergy resides at /opt, I don't remember why I put it there):

    <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<!DOCTYPE plist PUBLIC "-//Apple Computer//DTD PLIST 1.0//EN"
  "http://www.apple.com/DTDs/PropertyList-1.0.dtd">
<plist version="1.0">
<dict>
  <key>Label</key>
    <string>net.sourceforge.synergys</string>
  <key>OnDemand</key>
    <false/>
  <key>ProgramArguments</key>
  <array>
    <string>/opt/synergy/synergys</string>
    <string>-f</string>
    <string>--config</string>
    <string>/opt/synergy/synergy.conf</string>
  </array>
  <key>RunAtLoad</key>
  <key>StandardErrorPath</key>
    <string>/dev/null</string>
  <key>StandardOutPath</key>
    <string>/dev/null</string>
</dict>
</plist>

    (you can call it whatever you like under label)

    Save it as synergy.plist, /Library/LaunchDaemons is owned by root:wheel so you'll need to sudo everything. The -f runs it in foreground (ie. non-daemon) mode and launchd then "daemonises" it - synergy running in daemon mode forks and exits after starting, and launchd doesn't allow that.

  3. Next, you need to tell launchd to load this daemon:

    sudo launchctl load /Library/LaunchDaemons/synergy.plist

  4. So that's pretty much it, now synergy will fire up during the startup sequence, completely transparent. You might need to give it a kick sometimes (the software is not perfect), which you can do with launchctl. Without parameters, this will drop you in an interactive mode where you can do what you need to:

    list to show all the daemons running
    stop and start a job from above

    Don't forget to sudo launchctl, it's running as root.

  • http://www.afp548.com/forum/viewtopic.php?showtopic=12565
  • If you fear the terminal, Peter Borg has another sweet sweet program for you: Lingon.
  • You could also use the SynergyKM GUI, but where's the fun in that?

item.title: Backup and restore a MySQL database
item.description:
Backup from shell:

mysqldump -uroot -e schema > file.sql

If the target is phpmyadmin on MySQL 4.x (a sadly common config), you need to strip out charset info:

mysqldump -uroot -e --quick --compact schema > file.sql

To restore at shell:

mysql -uroot schema < file.sql

The Migrator:

mysqldump -uroot -e -A > db.sql
  • http://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/5.0/en/mysqldump.html

item.description:

GRANT ALL PRIVILEGES ON *.* TO 'user'@'localhost'
  IDENTIFIED BY 'password' WITH GRANT OPTION;
  • http://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/5.0/en/adding-users.html

item.title: Config Mutt to read from IMAP
item.description:

set spoolfile="imap://user:password@localhost/INBOX"

Easy.
